message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings described constitute a triad characteristic of Trisomy 18 (Edward Syndrome): micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears. Other clues include upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, clenched fists, overlapping digits, widely spaced nipples, prominent heels and rounded soles. Maternal alcohol intake would cause fetal alcohol syndrome, which may present with microcephaly and a smooth philtrum. Trisomy of chromosome 21 (Down Syndrome) would present with intellectual disability and characteristic facial features, such as a flattened face and upward slanting eyes, but not the other physical findings described. FMR1 gene silencing would suggest Fragile X Syndrome, which may cause intellectual disability and autistic-like behavior, but does not present with the same physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, low-set ears, upward slanting eyes, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, widely spaced nipples, and prominent heels with convex soles is a classic presentation of Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. Maternal alcohol intake can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, which has a different presentation. Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, presents with a different set of physical features. FMR1 gene silencing is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which also has a distinct presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical findings in the newborn are consistent with the diagnosis of trisomy of chromosome 18 (Edwards syndrome), which is characterized by micrognathia, prominent occiput, upward slanting eyes, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and a small palpebral fissure. Maternal alcohol intake can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, which may also have some physical abnormalities, but not the specific findings mentioned in this case. Trisomy of chromosome 21 (Down syndrome) has its own set of physical characteristics, and FMR1 gene silencing is associated with fragile X syndrome, neither of which match the described findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn presents with multiple abnormalities, including micrognathia, prominent occiput, low-set ears, upward-slanting eyes, clenched fists, overlapping fingers, a heart murmur, widely spaced nipples, and prominent heels with convex soles. These features are consistent with trisomy of chromosome 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. Trisomy of chromosome 21, also known as Down syndrome, can present with similar features but typically has a different combination of abnormalities. Maternal alcohol intake can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome, which can cause abnormalities but does not typically present with this specific combination of features. FMR1 gene silencing can cause fragile X syndrome, which also presents differently.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical findings suggest the baby has multiple abnormalities, including micrognathia, pointy low-set ears, upward slanting eyes, clenched fists, overlapping fingers, widely spaced nipples, and prominent heels and rounded soles of the feet. All these are typical findings in infants with trisomy 18. Trisomy of chromosome 21 can cause Down Syndrome, which presents with different physical abnormalities. Maternal alcohol intake can cause Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, which again presents with different physical abnormalities. FMR1 gene silencing can cause Fragile X Syndrome, which also presents with different physical and developmental abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings are consistent with Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) would present with a single palmar crease, not clenched fists, and FMR1 gene silencing (Fragile X syndrome) would not present with the physical features described. Maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy may cause a range of physical and cognitive abnormalities, but not the specific findings described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), which includes micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, low-set and abnormal ears, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, heart defects, widely spaced nipples, and distinctive foot abnormalities. Trisomy of chromosome 21 (Down syndrome) would have different physical features, while maternal alcohol intake and FMR1 gene silencing are not associated with these physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the newborn's physical characteristics and medical history suggests Trisomy of chromosome 18 (Edwards syndrome). Micrognathia, flattened nasal bridge, low-set ears, small palpebral fissures, overlapping fingers, pinky finger overlapping the fourth finger, prominent heels, and convex, rounded soles are physical characteristic findings of Trisomy 18.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical features described are consistent with a diagnosis of Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome). The combination of micrognathia, prominent occiput, flattened nasal bridge, pointy low-set ears, upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, widely spaced nipples, and prominent heels with rounded soles are characteristic features of Trisomy 18. Maternal alcohol intake may cause fetal alcohol syndrome but the physical findings do not match those described in the scenario. Trisomy of chromosome 21 causes Down syndrome, which has different physical findings than Trisomy 18. FMR1 gene silencing is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which also has different physical findings than Trisomy 18.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has multiple physical abnormalities including micrognathia, low-set ears, small palpebral fissures, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, widely spaced nipples, prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. These findings suggest Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, has a different set of physical characteristics such as a single palmar crease and a flat facial profile. Maternal alcohol intake can cause Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, but the physical characteristics are different. FMR1 gene silencing results in Fragile X Syndrome, which also has a different set of physical and neurological characteristics.
